domains.name: People
domains.description: Skills and activities associated with effectively leading a project team

tasks.name: Manage conflict
tasks.description: Enable team members to resolve their conflicts

flashcards.question: What are the five conflict resolution techniques in order from most collaborative to least collaborative?
flashcards.answer: 1. Collaborate/Problem Solve (win-win), 2. Compromise (lose-lose), 3. Smooth/Accommodate (yield-lose), 4. Force/Direct (win-lose), 5. Withdraw/Avoid (lose-leave)

flashcards.question: What is the most effective conflict resolution technique for long-term solutions?
flashcards.answer: Collaborate/Problem Solve - It addresses the root cause and creates a win-win solution where all parties' concerns are heard and integrated into the solution.

flashcards.question: When should a project manager use the Withdraw/Avoid conflict resolution technique?
flashcards.answer: When emotions are high and parties need time to cool down, when the issue is trivial, or when gathering more information is needed before addressing the conflict.

tasks.name: Lead a team
tasks.description: Support team performance through all project phases

flashcards.question: What are the five stages of Tuckman's Team Development model?
flashcards.answer: 1. Forming (getting to know each other), 2. Storming (conflicts emerge), 3. Norming (establishing processes), 4. Performing (working efficiently), 5. Adjourning (project completion)

flashcards.question: What is servant leadership and why is it important in project management?
flashcards.answer: Servant leadership is a leadership style where the leader prioritizes the needs of the team, removes obstacles, and enables team members to perform at their best. It's important because it builds trust, empowers the team, and creates a collaborative environment.

flashcards.question: What is the difference between power and authority in project management?
flashcards.answer: Power is the ability to influence others' behavior, while authority is the legitimate right to make decisions and give orders. A PM may have authority from their role but must earn power through expertise, relationships, and trust.

flashcards.question: What are the key characteristics of a high-performing team?
flashcards.answer: Clear goals, defined roles, open communication, mutual trust, shared accountability, collaborative decision-making, continuous improvement mindset, and effective conflict resolution.

tasks.name: Support team performance
tasks.description: Evaluate team member and overall team performance

flashcards.question: What is Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs and how does it apply to team motivation?
flashcards.answer: Maslow's Hierarchy has 5 levels: Physiological, Safety, Social/Belonging, Esteem, and Self-Actualization. Teams perform best when lower-level needs (salary, job security) are met, allowing focus on higher-level needs (recognition, growth).

flashcards.question: What is Herzberg's Two-Factor Theory (Motivation-Hygiene Theory)?
flashcards.answer: Hygiene factors (salary, working conditions, policies) prevent dissatisfaction but don't motivate. Motivators (achievement, recognition, responsibility, growth) actually drive satisfaction and performance.

flashcards.question: What is the difference between Theory X and Theory Y management styles?
flashcards.answer: Theory X assumes people dislike work and need close supervision. Theory Y assumes people are self-motivated and seek responsibility. Modern PM favors Theory Y, promoting empowerment and trust.

flashcards.question: What metrics can be used to assess team performance?
flashcards.answer: Velocity, quality metrics (defect rates), team morale surveys, collaboration effectiveness, knowledge sharing, adherence to schedules, and achievement of team objectives.

tasks.name: Empower team members and stakeholders
tasks.description: Authorize team members and stakeholders to make decisions

flashcards.question: What is the difference between delegation and empowerment?
flashcards.answer: Delegation is assigning specific tasks while retaining accountability. Empowerment is giving authority and autonomy to make decisions and take ownership, sharing both responsibility and accountability.

flashcards.question: What are the benefits of empowering team members?
flashcards.answer: Increased motivation and engagement, faster decision-making, development of team capabilities, better problem-solving through diverse perspectives, and reduced PM bottlenecks.

flashcards.question: What is a decision-making framework that can help empower teams?
flashcards.answer: RACI matrix (Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed) clearly defines who makes decisions, who must be consulted, and who needs to be informed, enabling appropriate empowerment levels.

tasks.name: Build a team
tasks.description: Grow team capabilities and improve team performance

flashcards.question: What are the key strategies for building an effective project team?
flashcards.answer: Clear role definition, skill development opportunities, team-building activities, co-location when possible, ground rules establishment, recognition and rewards, and fostering collaboration.

flashcards.question: What is a cross-functional team and why is it valuable?
flashcards.answer: A team with members from different functional areas (development, testing, design, business). It's valuable because it brings diverse perspectives, reduces handoffs, enables faster decisions, and improves overall product quality.

flashcards.question: What is T-shaped skill development?
flashcards.answer: Having deep expertise in one area (vertical bar of T) while also having broad knowledge across multiple areas (horizontal bar). This creates more flexible, collaborative team members.

flashcards.question: What are effective team recognition strategies?
flashcards.answer: Public acknowledgment, peer recognition programs, celebrating milestones, individual appreciation for specific contributions, and aligning rewards with team values and achievements.

tasks.name: Address and remove impediments, obstacles, and blockers
tasks.description: Identify and remove factors that hinder team progress

flashcards.question: What is the difference between an impediment, obstacle, and blocker?
flashcards.answer: Impediments slow progress, obstacles make progress difficult, and blockers completely stop progress. All need to be addressed, but blockers require immediate attention.

flashcards.question: What is an impediment backlog?
flashcards.answer: A prioritized list of impediments that tracks issues blocking team progress, including description, impact, status, and owner. It helps ensure impediments are visible and systematically resolved.

flashcards.question: What techniques can help identify hidden impediments?
flashcards.answer: Regular retrospectives, daily standups, one-on-ones with team members, impediment boards, process mapping to identify bottlenecks, and creating psychological safety for raising issues.

tasks.name: Negotiate project agreements
tasks.description: Reach agreement on project terms and conditions

flashcards.question: What are the key principles of win-win negotiation?
flashcards.answer: Focus on interests not positions, separate people from the problem, generate multiple options before deciding, use objective criteria, develop BATNA (Best Alternative to Negotiated Agreement).

flashcards.question: What is BATNA and why is it important in negotiations?
flashcards.answer: Best Alternative to Negotiated Agreement - your fallback option if negotiations fail. Knowing your BATNA gives you negotiating power and helps determine when to walk away from unfavorable terms.

flashcards.question: What items are typically negotiated in project agreements?
flashcards.answer: Scope, schedule, budget, quality standards, resource allocation, risk allocation, change control processes, acceptance criteria, payment terms, and contract type.

tasks.name: Collaborate with stakeholders
tasks.description: Work with stakeholders to achieve mutual understanding

flashcards.question: What is the Salience Model for stakeholder analysis?
flashcards.answer: Classifies stakeholders based on three attributes: Power (ability to influence), Legitimacy (valid claim to be involved), and Urgency (time-sensitivity of their needs). Stakeholders with all three are definitive stakeholders requiring highest attention.

flashcards.question: What is the Power/Interest Grid for stakeholder management?
flashcards.answer: Maps stakeholders on two dimensions: Power (high/low) and Interest (high/low). High power/high interest = Manage Closely, High power/low interest = Keep Satisfied, Low power/high interest = Keep Informed, Low power/low interest = Monitor.

flashcards.question: What are effective strategies for managing resistant stakeholders?
flashcards.answer: Understand their concerns, involve them early, communicate benefits, address objections directly, find win-win solutions, leverage influential supporters, and demonstrate quick wins.

flashcards.question: What is a stakeholder engagement assessment matrix?
flashcards.answer: A tool that maps each stakeholder's current engagement level vs. desired engagement level (Unaware, Resistant, Neutral, Supportive, Leading), helping plan engagement strategies to close gaps.

tasks.name: Promote team performance through emotional intelligence
tasks.description: Use emotional intelligence to improve team effectiveness

flashcards.question: What are the four components of Emotional Intelligence according to Daniel Goleman?
flashcards.answer: 1. Self-awareness (understanding your emotions), 2. Self-management (controlling your emotions), 3. Social awareness (understanding others' emotions), 4. Relationship management (using emotional understanding to interact effectively).

flashcards.question: How does emotional intelligence benefit project teams?
flashcards.answer: Better conflict resolution, improved communication, stronger relationships, increased trust, better decision-making under stress, higher team morale, and more effective leadership.

flashcards.question: What techniques can improve self-awareness in project managers?
flashcards.answer: Regular self-reflection, seeking feedback, journaling, mindfulness practices, personality assessments, and recognizing emotional triggers and patterns.

tasks.name: Execute project with urgency to deliver business value
tasks.description: Deliver project outcomes at frequent intervals

flashcards.question: What is the difference between incremental and iterative delivery?
flashcards.answer: Incremental delivery adds functionality piece by piece (building blocks). Iterative delivery repeatedly refines the same functionality (successive refinement). Most agile approaches use both.

flashcards.question: What is a Minimum Viable Product (MVP)?
flashcards.answer: The smallest version of a product that delivers value to customers and provides learning opportunities. It has just enough features to satisfy early adopters and validate product assumptions.

flashcards.question: What is the purpose of timeboxing in agile projects?
flashcards.answer: Timeboxing sets fixed durations for activities (sprints, meetings), forcing prioritization, preventing scope creep, creating rhythm, and ensuring regular delivery of value.

tasks.name: Manage communications
tasks.description: Ensure effective information exchange

flashcards.question: What is the formula for calculating communication channels?
flashcards.answer: n(n-1)/2, where n is the number of people. For example, with 5 people: 5(4)/2 = 10 channels. This shows how complexity increases with team size.

flashcards.question: What are the five communication methods in order of effectiveness?
flashcards.answer: 1. Interactive (most effective - real-time two-way), 2. Push (sent to recipients), 3. Pull (recipients access at their convenience). Interactive includes meetings and calls; Push includes emails; Pull includes websites/repositories.

flashcards.question: What is the communication model and its key components?
flashcards.answer: Sender → Encode → Message → Medium → Decode → Receiver → Feedback. Noise can interfere at any stage. Effective communication requires clear encoding, appropriate medium, and confirming understanding through feedback.

flashcards.question: What percentage of communication is non-verbal according to Mehrabian's research?
flashcards.answer: 93% (55% body language, 38% tone of voice, only 7% actual words). This emphasizes the importance of face-to-face communication for complex or sensitive topics.

flashcards.question: What is active listening and what are its key techniques?
flashcards.answer: Fully concentrating on the speaker. Techniques include: maintaining eye contact, asking clarifying questions, paraphrasing to confirm understanding, avoiding interruptions, and being aware of non-verbal cues.

tasks.name: Assess and manage risks
tasks.description: Identify and manage threats and opportunities

flashcards.question: What are the four risk response strategies for threats?
flashcards.answer: 1. Avoid (eliminate the threat), 2. Mitigate (reduce probability or impact), 3. Transfer (shift to third party), 4. Accept (acknowledge but take no action).

flashcards.question: What are the four risk response strategies for opportunities?
flashcards.answer: 1. Exploit (ensure it happens), 2. Enhance (increase probability or impact), 3. Share (allocate to third party who can best capture it), 4. Accept (don't actively pursue).

flashcards.question: How is Expected Monetary Value (EMV) calculated?
flashcards.answer: EMV = Probability × Impact. For example, a 30% probability of a $10,000 loss = -$3,000 EMV. Used in decision tree analysis to choose between alternatives.

flashcards.question: What is the difference between qualitative and quantitative risk analysis?
flashcards.answer: Qualitative uses subjective assessment (high/medium/low probability and impact, priority ranking). Quantitative uses numerical analysis (EMV, Monte Carlo simulation, decision trees) for critical risks.

flashcards.question: What is a risk register and what does it contain?
flashcards.answer: A document tracking all identified risks with: risk description, category, probability, impact, priority, response strategy, owner, status, and trigger conditions. It's a living document updated throughout the project.

flashcards.question: What is risk appetite vs. risk tolerance vs. risk threshold?
flashcards.answer: Risk appetite is the degree of uncertainty an organization is willing to accept. Risk tolerance is the degree of variation acceptable around objectives. Risk threshold is the specific point where risk becomes unacceptable.

tasks.name: Engage stakeholders
tasks.description: Build relationships and communicate to satisfy needs

flashcards.question: What is the difference between stakeholder identification and stakeholder analysis?
flashcards.answer: Identification is finding all stakeholders. Analysis is understanding their power, interest, influence, expectations, and how to engage them effectively through tools like Power/Interest Grid or Salience Model.

flashcards.question: What should be included in a stakeholder engagement plan?
flashcards.answer: Stakeholder list, their interests/expectations, engagement level (current/desired), communication requirements, engagement strategies, and frequency/methods of interaction.

flashcards.question: Why is early stakeholder engagement important?
flashcards.answer: Identifies requirements and expectations early, builds buy-in and support, reduces resistance to change, uncovers risks and constraints, and influences project direction when changes are least expensive.

tasks.name: Plan and manage budget and resources
tasks.description: Estimate and allocate resources and budget

flashcards.question: What is the difference between a cost estimate and a budget?
flashcards.answer: A cost estimate predicts how much the project will cost. A budget allocates that estimate over time with contingency reserves, forming the cost baseline for monitoring and control.

flashcards.question: What are the three types of cost estimates and their accuracy ranges?
flashcards.answer: 1. Rough Order of Magnitude (ROM): -25% to +75%, 2. Budget estimate: -10% to +25%, 3. Definitive estimate: -5% to +10%. Accuracy increases as more information becomes available.

flashcards.question: What is the Cost Performance Index (CPI) and how is it calculated?
flashcards.answer: CPI = EV / AC (Earned Value / Actual Cost). CPI > 1.0 means under budget (good), CPI < 1.0 means over budget (bad). It measures cost efficiency.

flashcards.question: What is the Schedule Performance Index (SPI) and how is it calculated?
flashcards.answer: SPI = EV / PV (Earned Value / Planned Value). SPI > 1.0 means ahead of schedule (good), SPI < 1.0 means behind schedule (bad). It measures schedule efficiency.

flashcards.question: What is Estimate at Completion (EAC) and what are the common formulas?
flashcards.answer: EAC projects total cost at completion. Common formulas: 1. EAC = BAC/CPI (current CPI continues), 2. EAC = AC + (BAC-EV) (atypical variance), 3. EAC = AC + Bottom-up estimate (major change).

flashcards.question: What is the difference between management reserve and contingency reserve?
flashcards.answer: Contingency reserve is for identified risks (known unknowns) and is part of the cost baseline. Management reserve is for unidentified risks (unknown unknowns) and is outside the baseline, requiring stakeholder approval to use.

tasks.name: Plan and manage schedule
tasks.description: Estimate task duration and sequence activities

flashcards.question: What is the Critical Path Method (CPM)?
flashcards.answer: A technique to determine the longest path through a project network diagram, identifying the minimum project duration. Activities on the critical path have zero float and any delay extends the project.

flashcards.question: What is float (slack) and how is it calculated?
flashcards.answer: Float is the amount of time an activity can be delayed without delaying the project. Total Float = LS - ES or LF - EF. Free Float is time an activity can be delayed without delaying successor's early start.

flashcards.question: What are the four types of dependencies between activities?
flashcards.answer: 1. Finish-to-Start (FS) - most common, 2. Finish-to-Finish (FF), 3. Start-to-Start (SS), 4. Start-to-Finish (SF) - rare. Can include leads (overlap) or lags (delay).

flashcards.question: What is the difference between leads and lags in scheduling?
flashcards.answer: A lead allows acceleration, starting a successor before predecessor finishes (negative time). A lag is a delay between activities, requiring wait time before the successor can start (positive time).

flashcards.question: What is Fast Tracking vs. Crashing?
flashcards.answer: Fast Tracking does activities in parallel that were planned in sequence (increases risk). Crashing adds resources to critical path activities (increases cost). Both are schedule compression techniques.

flashcards.question: What is the Three-Point Estimating formula using PERT?
flashcards.answer: Expected Duration = (Optimistic + 4×Most Likely + Pessimistic) / 6. Standard Deviation = (Pessimistic - Optimistic) / 6. Provides more accurate estimates than single-point estimates.

tasks.name: Plan and manage quality
tasks.description: Establish quality standards and ensure they are met

flashcards.question: What is the difference between quality assurance (QA) and quality control (QC)?
flashcards.answer: QA is proactive, preventing defects through process improvement and following best practices. QC is reactive, detecting defects through inspection and testing of deliverables.

flashcards.question: What is the Cost of Quality and its four components?
flashcards.answer: Total cost of quality efforts: 1. Prevention costs (training, process design), 2. Appraisal costs (testing, inspections), 3. Internal failure costs (rework, scrap), 4. External failure costs (warranties, liability, lost business).

flashcards.question: What is the difference between precision and accuracy?
flashcards.answer: Precision is consistency/repeatability of measurements (tight grouping). Accuracy is correctness of measurements (closeness to true value). Ideal is both precise and accurate.

flashcards.question: What is Continuous Improvement (Kaizen) and how is it implemented?
flashcards.answer: Philosophy of ongoing incremental improvements. Implemented through Plan-Do-Check-Act (PDCA) cycles, retrospectives, root cause analysis, and creating a culture where everyone suggests improvements.

flashcards.question: What are the 7 Basic Quality Tools?
flashcards.answer: 1. Cause and Effect Diagram (Fishbone), 2. Flowcharts, 3. Check Sheets, 4. Pareto Charts, 5. Histograms, 6. Control Charts, 7. Scatter Diagrams. Used for quality planning, control, and improvement.

tasks.name: Plan and manage scope
tasks.description: Define and control what is included in the project

flashcards.question: What is the difference between product scope and project scope?
flashcards.answer: Product scope defines features and functions of the product/deliverable. Project scope is the work required to deliver the product, including all project management activities.

flashcards.question: What is a Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) and what is the 100% rule?
flashcards.answer: WBS is a hierarchical decomposition of total project scope into manageable work packages. The 100% rule states the WBS must include 100% of the work defined by scope - no more, no less.

flashcards.question: What is scope creep vs. gold plating?
flashcards.answer: Scope creep is uncontrolled expansion of scope without adjusting time, cost, or resources. Gold plating is adding extra features beyond requirements without approval. Both harm projects.

flashcards.question: What is Progressive Elaboration?
flashcards.answer: Continuously improving and detailing the project plan as more information becomes available. Common in projects with high uncertainty. Details increase over time through iterations.

tasks.name: Integrate project planning activities
tasks.description: Consolidate all project plans into a cohesive whole

flashcards.question: What is the Project Management Plan and what does it include?
flashcards.answer: The comprehensive document integrating all subsidiary plans (scope, schedule, cost, quality, resource, communications, risk, procurement, stakeholder management) and baselines. It guides execution, monitoring, and control.

flashcards.question: What is a project baseline and what are the three main baselines?
flashcards.answer: A baseline is an approved version used for comparison. The three main baselines are: Scope Baseline (scope statement, WBS, WBS dictionary), Schedule Baseline, and Cost Baseline. Together they form the Performance Measurement Baseline.

flashcards.question: What is the purpose of configuration management?
flashcards.answer: Systematically controlling changes to project artifacts, maintaining integrity and traceability. Includes version control, change control, status accounting, and configuration audits.

tasks.name: Manage project changes
tasks.description: Manage changes to project scope, schedule, and costs

flashcards.question: What is the purpose of a Change Control Board (CCB)?
flashcards.answer: A formally designated group responsible for reviewing, evaluating, approving, deferring, or rejecting changes to the project, and recording and communicating decisions.

flashcards.question: What is Integrated Change Control?
flashcards.answer: The process of reviewing all change requests, approving changes, managing changes to deliverables/plans/documents, and communicating decisions. It ensures changes are beneficial and properly evaluated for impact.

flashcards.question: What should be included in a change request?
flashcards.answer: Description of change, justification/reason, impact analysis (scope, schedule, cost, quality, risk), alternatives considered, recommendation, and priority level.

tasks.name: Plan and manage procurement
tasks.description: Define procurement needs and manage vendor relationships

flashcards.question: What are the three main contract types and their risk profiles?
flashcards.answer: 1. Fixed Price (FP) - seller has most risk, buyer has least, 2. Cost Reimbursable (CR) - buyer has most risk, seller has least, 3. Time & Materials (T&M) - moderate risk for both parties.

flashcards.question: What is a Make-or-Buy analysis?
flashcards.answer: Evaluating whether to produce internally or purchase externally based on: cost comparison, capacity, expertise, quality control, risk, timeline, and strategic considerations.

flashcards.question: What is the difference between an RFP, RFQ, and RFI?
flashcards.answer: RFI (Request for Information) - gather information, RFQ (Request for Quote) - price-focused for standard items, RFP (Request for Proposal) - comprehensive proposals for complex needs including technical and cost details.

tasks.name: Manage project artifacts
tasks.description: Maintain project documents and records

flashcards.question: What is the difference between project documents and the project management plan?
flashcards.answer: The project management plan is the integrated, approved document guiding the project. Project documents are separate supporting documents (registers, logs, reports) that may be updated without formal change control.

flashcards.question: What are examples of key project artifacts?
flashcards.answer: Project charter, project management plan, requirements documentation, risk register, issue log, change log, lessons learned register, stakeholder register, and various reports (status, performance, quality).

tasks.name: Determine appropriate project methodology
tasks.description: Select the best project approach based on context

flashcards.question: When is a predictive (waterfall) approach most appropriate?
flashcards.answer: When requirements are well-defined and stable, technology is mature, regulatory compliance requires extensive documentation, and stakeholders need cost/schedule certainty upfront.

flashcards.question: When is an adaptive (agile) approach most appropriate?
flashcards.answer: When requirements are unclear or evolving, rapid feedback is needed, innovation is valued, team can self-organize, and incremental delivery provides value.

flashcards.question: What is a hybrid approach and when is it used?
flashcards.answer: Combining predictive and adaptive elements. Used when some parts need upfront planning (hardware, compliance) while others benefit from agility (software, UX). Tailors methodology to project needs.

flashcards.question: What factors influence methodology selection?
flashcards.answer: Project characteristics (size, complexity, uncertainty), organizational culture, team capability, stakeholder preferences, regulatory requirements, and degree of innovation required.

domains.name: Business Environment
domains.description: Connection between projects and organizational strategy

tasks.name: Plan and manage project compliance
tasks.description: Ensure project adheres to regulations and requirements

flashcards.question: What is the difference between compliance and conformance?
flashcards.answer: Compliance is adherence to external requirements (laws, regulations, standards). Conformance is meeting internal specifications and quality standards. Both are important for project success.

flashcards.question: What are common areas requiring project compliance?
flashcards.answer: Legal regulations, industry standards, environmental requirements, safety regulations, data privacy laws (GDPR, CCPA), financial reporting, labor laws, and organizational policies.

flashcards.question: How should compliance requirements be managed throughout the project?
flashcards.answer: Identify early, document in requirements, assign compliance owner, integrate into quality plan, conduct regular audits, maintain evidence/documentation, and stay current with regulatory changes.

tasks.name: Evaluate and deliver project benefits and value
tasks.description: Assess project value delivery and benefits realization

flashcards.question: What is the difference between outputs, outcomes, and benefits?
flashcards.answer: Outputs are tangible deliverables produced. Outcomes are the results of using outputs (behavior changes). Benefits are the measurable value gained from outcomes (increased revenue, reduced costs).

flashcards.question: What is a Benefits Realization Plan?
flashcards.answer: Document defining target benefits, metrics, timeframes, owners, and how benefits will be measured and tracked. Often benefits are realized after project completion, requiring ongoing measurement.

flashcards.question: What is Return on Investment (ROI) and how is it calculated?
flashcards.answer: ROI = (Net Profit / Investment) × 100. Measures financial return as a percentage. For example, if a $100K project generates $150K profit, ROI = 50%. Used to compare investment alternatives.

flashcards.question: What is Net Present Value (NPV)?
flashcards.answer: The present value of future cash flows minus initial investment. Positive NPV means project adds value. Higher NPV is better. Accounts for time value of money (money today is worth more than future money).

flashcards.question: What is Payback Period?
flashcards.answer: Time required to recover the initial investment from project benefits. Shorter payback is better. Example: $200K investment with $50K annual returns has 4-year payback period. Simple but doesn't account for time value of money.

tasks.name: Evaluate and address internal and external business environment changes
tasks.description: Assess and respond to environmental factors affecting the project

flashcards.question: What are Enterprise Environmental Factors (EEFs)?
flashcards.answer: External and internal conditions not under project team control that influence the project: organizational culture, market conditions, regulations, infrastructure, resource availability, and political climate.

flashcards.question: What are Organizational Process Assets (OPAs)?
flashcards.answer: Plans, processes, policies, procedures, and knowledge bases specific to the organization: templates, historical information, lessons learned, standards, guidelines, and communication requirements.

flashcards.question: What is PESTLE analysis?
flashcards.answer: Framework for analyzing macro-environmental factors: Political, Economic, Social, Technological, Legal, Environmental. Helps identify external factors that may impact the project.

flashcards.question: What is VUCA and how does it affect project management?
flashcards.answer: Volatility, Uncertainty, Complexity, Ambiguity - characteristics of modern business environment. VUCA conditions favor adaptive approaches, frequent re-planning, and strong stakeholder engagement.

tasks.name: Support organizational change
tasks.description: Enable transition to future state defined by project outcomes

flashcards.question: What is Kotter's 8-Step Change Model?
flashcards.answer: 1. Create urgency, 2. Build guiding coalition, 3. Form strategic vision, 4. Enlist volunteer army, 5. Enable action by removing barriers, 6. Generate short-term wins, 7. Sustain acceleration, 8. Institute change.

flashcards.question: What is the ADKAR model for change management?
flashcards.answer: Five building blocks for successful change: Awareness (why change), Desire (want to support), Knowledge (how to change), Ability (skills to implement), Reinforcement (sustaining change). Individual-focused model.

flashcards.question: What are common reasons people resist change?
flashcards.answer: Fear of the unknown, loss of control, disruption of routine, perceived negative impact, lack of trust, poor communication, past negative experiences, and not understanding the 'why'.

flashcards.question: What strategies help overcome resistance to change?
flashcards.answer: Communicate clearly and often, involve stakeholders early, show WIIFM (What's In It For Me), provide training and support, celebrate quick wins, address concerns directly, and secure leadership commitment.

tasks.name: Employ continuous process improvement
tasks.description: Continuously improve project processes and practices

flashcards.question: What is the Plan-Do-Check-Act (PDCA) cycle?
flashcards.answer: Continuous improvement framework: Plan (identify improvement), Do (implement on small scale), Check (evaluate results), Act (standardize if successful or try again). Also called Deming Cycle.

flashcards.question: What is the purpose of a retrospective?
flashcards.answer: Team meeting to reflect on what went well, what didn't, and what to improve. Held regularly (end of sprint/phase) to enable continuous learning and process improvement. Key agile practice.

flashcards.question: What is the 5 Whys technique?
flashcards.answer: Root cause analysis method asking 'Why?' repeatedly (typically five times) to drill down from symptoms to underlying cause. Simple but effective for identifying true problems to solve.

flashcards.question: What is benchmarking in continuous improvement?
flashcards.answer: Comparing organizational processes and performance metrics to industry best practices or competitors. Identifies performance gaps and opportunities for improvement.

tasks.name: Build shared understanding
tasks.description: Establish common understanding among stakeholders

flashcards.question: What is a working agreement and why is it important?
flashcards.answer: Team-created guidelines defining how members will work together: meeting norms, communication preferences, decision-making process, conflict resolution. Builds alignment and reduces friction.

flashcards.question: What techniques help build shared understanding?
flashcards.answer: Collaborative workshops, visual models (diagrams, prototypes), active listening, asking clarifying questions, summarizing and confirming understanding, and using common terminology/glossary.

flashcards.question: What is a project vision statement and what should it include?
flashcards.answer: Concise description of the desired future state the project will create. Should inspire and align stakeholders by answering: What are we building? Why? Who benefits? What value does it create?

tasks.name: Manage project knowledge
tasks.description: Ensure knowledge is created, shared, and used effectively

flashcards.question: What is the difference between explicit and tacit knowledge?
flashcards.answer: Explicit knowledge is codified and easily shared (documents, procedures). Tacit knowledge is experience-based, intuitive, and harder to articulate (expertise, insights). Both are valuable.

flashcards.question: What is a lessons learned register and when should it be updated?
flashcards.answer: Repository capturing what went well and what could be improved, with recommendations. Should be updated throughout the project (not just at the end) and shared across the organization.

flashcards.question: What strategies facilitate knowledge transfer?
flashcards.answer: Documentation, mentoring/shadowing, communities of practice, knowledge sharing sessions, pair programming, rotation programs, and maintaining accessible knowledge repositories.

tasks.name: Monitor and report project performance
tasks.description: Track progress and communicate status

flashcards.question: What is variance analysis?
flashcards.answer: Comparing actual performance against baselines to identify deviations. Includes schedule variance (SV = EV - PV), cost variance (CV = EV - AC), and determining root causes and corrective actions.

flashcards.question: What should be included in a project status report?
flashcards.answer: Summary of progress, milestone status, budget status, key accomplishments, upcoming activities, risks and issues, changes, metrics/KPIs, and any requests for stakeholder decisions.

flashcards.question: What are Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)?
flashcards.answer: Measurable values demonstrating project effectiveness: on-time delivery, budget adherence, quality metrics, stakeholder satisfaction, team productivity, and defect rates. Should be SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound).
